Used to crew on off-shore sailboat races on Lake Michigan in my younger days.  It was fairly common to have a bat or 2 land on the boat during the night when we were out of sight of land.  Lots of times, they'd basically "crash land" on the boat out of sheer exhaustion, and we'd have to gently pick them up and place them somewhere safe while they rested up.   There was even a few that wouldn't leave.  We'd finally get into port and have to "transfer" them to the nearest tree.  poor l'il guys!  

Had the same thing happen with small birds during the day at times as well.  They'd land on the life lines right next to you, or up in the rigging somewhere and rest up for a couple hours before heading on their merry way.

The domestic cat is the single most destructive pet in history.  I don't hate them (I've owned several), but they are absolutely devastating to wildlife wherever they're allowed to roam outside their homes, and if they go feral they can and have caused extinction events.  One famous example was a cat named Tibbles that lived at a lighthouse on Stephens Island in 1894.  The last remaining colony of Lyall's Wrens happened to reside on that same island; they once had been widespread throughout New Zealand but were hunted to extinction by the Maori.  Lyall's Wrens were small, flightless birds, and Tibbles killed every last one of them.

Unfortunately, it's what cats do.  And even when well-fed, they do so for pure sport, as it were, sometimes to an obsessive degree.

Australia estimates that domestic and feral cats in particular account for BILLIONS of wildlife deaths there every year, often involving species that are already endangered.  While other countries generally don't keep such detailed records, the full toll the domestic housecat has taken on global wildlife is appalling.

It goes without saying that pet cats should be kept indoors at all times and that feral populations are a menace.  On a deeper level it also goes to show how they're a fitting companion for humans, since we tend to destroy everything we touch.

I just felt the urge to post this upon reading the headline, because like countless others, this bat's death was both tragic and unnecessary.

replies.context: Bats can get and spread it, and clearly fly quite a distance. Yet people believe the answer to stopping the spread is to vaccinate all the people and lock all the people down. Let's just forget that there are at *least* 20 times more bats int he world than people.

Okay, time to take your meds.  SARS CoV-2 is an engineered virus; there is exactly zero evidence that a bat-human interface is responsible for COVID spreading to the human population, and a growing mountain of evidence that Chinese virologists (with Fauci bankrolling them) took a coronavirus with an affinity for bats and tinkered with it until they succeeded in switching it's affinity to human.  Perhaps you should refrain from operating machinery until you are examined by a healthcare professional...

I didn't say it was the responsible mechanism for its introduction. I did say bats can get it and spread it, just like deer, cats (domestic and large), dogs, ferrets and minks that have all been demonstrated to do this. 

Try not to read what you already know into other's posts, and instead be open to learning new things. Trust me: people will like you better if you do.

Firstly, I don't give rat spit whether people like me or not.  I've been out of high school plenty long enough to have grown accustomed to myself independent of other's opinions.  Secondly, when the virus' affinity was changed to that of human it lost it's ability to transmit to animals.  I know of no study which demonstrated that deer or cats or dogs or any other animal can spread COVID to humans. Perhaps you'd like to share your source material?

Sure, let's start with:
University of Minnesota CIDRAP. "Covid-19 Likely spreading from people to animals and vice versa" reviews 3 studies on this topic. 

It is widely accepted that corona viruses do this all the time, and there is no reason to believe COVID 19 doesn't especially given the evidence that it has been found in the wide variety of mammals I noted above.

If people find you likeable, they might actually care what you think. I'm thinking from your general insulting and demeaning attitude that most people don't.  Which leads to be being even more of a jerk, and the cycle continues. But, by all means: you do you.

"Likely" means "I think."  It hardly substitutes for peer-reviewed data.  That COVID has been found in animals does NOT prove or even INDICATE it can be transmitted to humans.  As I said, there is zero empirical data to support that claim.  And I'm just fine with being called a jerk.  You can call me anything you want as long as you don't call me late for dinner.

So, you didn't read the studies they quoted, you're just attacking your misunderstanding of verbiage of the headline?

You would know, if you'd read any of the article, that the COVID found in cats is exactly the same COVID in humans. It doesn't translate or change. It is just exactly the same virus. It is 100% transmissible. 

And this is a lovely way to point out that the wording "likely" refers to the fact that one cannot see a particular viral particle that is transmitted, but finds overwhelming evidence that it is happening and therefore as a good scientist having healthy skepticism writes "likely." When you hear a scientist say "definitively" or "only possible mechanism" or such, alarm bells should go off in your head because that person is probably lying (either about being a scientist or about their results). Were a scientist to merely *think* something based on research of similar situations and/or experience they would properly use the word "hypothesize." In either case it is a great deal more meaningful than "I think."

I didn't call you a jerk. I merely am pointing out that the only person you're affecting with your insulting style is yourself and that you are pushing a cycle that doesn't lead to happy.
Still gnawing on this bone, are we?!?  Believe what you will and I shall do likewise.

Kinda figured you had your mind made up before you looked at any facts. Just like you went off half cocked about my first post over something I didn't actually write. Here's the thing: We probably  argue for the same basic things, but I find people like you detract rather than add to the weight of sensible arguments. So I made a a plea to you here to get some real understanding before shooting off your mouth. Don't be counting on this degree of kindness the next time I see you post.  I find willful ignorance abhorrent, no matter which side of the field it comes from. 

Have a blessed day!
